questions.questionText: Statements: All cats are animals. All animals need food. Conclusion: ?
questions.explanation: All cats are animals, and all animals need food, so all cats must need food

questions.questionText: Statements: All roses are flowers. All flowers are plants. Conclusion: ?
questions.explanation: All roses → flowers → plants, therefore all roses are plants

questions.questionText: Statements: No birds are mammals. All eagles are birds. Conclusion: ?
questions.explanation: All eagles are birds, and no birds are mammals, so no eagles are mammals

questions.questionText: Statements: Some books are novels. All novels are fiction. Conclusion: ?
questions.explanation: Some books are novels, and all novels are fiction, so some books must be fiction

questions.questionText: Statements: All dogs bark. Some animals bark. Conclusion: Can we conclude 'All dogs are animals'?
questions.explanation: The statements don't establish the relationship between dogs and animals definitively

questions.questionText: Statements: All teachers are educated. Some educated people are rich. Conclusion: ?
questions.explanation: We cannot determine if any teachers are among the 'some' educated people who are rich

questions.questionText: Statements: No cars are bikes. All bikes are vehicles. Conclusion: ?
questions.explanation: The relationship between cars and vehicles is not established by these statements

questions.questionText: Statements: All apples are fruits. All fruits are healthy. Conclusion: ?
questions.explanation: All apples → fruits → healthy, therefore all apples are healthy

questions.questionText: Statements: Some pens are blue. All blue things are colored. Conclusion: ?
questions.explanation: Some pens are blue, and all blue things are colored, so some pens must be colored

questions.questionText: Statements: No humans are perfect. All perfect things are divine. Conclusion: ?
questions.explanation: Cannot determine the relationship between humans and divine things from these statements
